repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - First Edo State Growth and
            Employment Support Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The First Edo State Growth and
            Employment Support Credit for Nigeria received a moderately
            satisfactory outcome rating with moderate risk to
            development outcome. Both the Bank and the Borrower received
            satisfactory ratings for their part in the project. The
            project was restructured to extend the closing date by one
            year. The extension was necessary to provide the Edo State
            Government with adequate time for the operation given the
            delay in national parliamentary approval of Nigerias
            2011/2012 External Borrowing Plan which in turn led to
            delays in the signing of the credit agreements and
            declaration of credit effectiveness. The project development
            objective (PDO) and key outcome indicators remained
            unchanged. There were several lessons learned from the
            project and include the following: (1) a key lesson is that
            the commitment of the State Government to reforms is
            critical to the success of the state-level subnational
            development policy operations (DPOs), (2) the use of DPOs at
            the state level to promote good governance and economic
            growth is increasingly motivating other state governments in
            Nigeria to sustain their reform-oriented programs, (3) the
            existence of complimentary projects with funding for
            technical assistance supported the implementation of prior
            actions and enhanced sustainability program reforms, (4) the
            use of private sector information communication and
            technology (ICT) experts helped with the speedy
            implementation of public sector modernization components of
            the DPO such as the integrated financial management
            information system (IFMIS) and education management
            information system (EMIS), and (5) mainstreaming the
            monitoring and evaluation (M&E) system during program
            implementation is critical for ensuring effective monitoring
            of progress being made on key development objective indicators.

Nigeria - First Edo State Growth and

repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - First Edo State Growth and
            Employment Support Credit Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the First Edo State
            Growth and Employment Support Credit Project for Nigeria is
            to support Edo state's critical reforms for improving
            the management of public resources and creating a better
            environment for growth and employment creation in a
            socially-accountable way. The extension is necessary to
            provide the Edo State Government with adequate time to
            utilize the credit as the approval of Nigeria's
            2012-2015 external borrowing plan by the National Assembly
            was delayed and only came through as part of the 2013-2015
            External Borrowing Plan in December, 2012. This has resulted
            in a delay of the signing of the credit agreements and
            declaration of credit effectiveness. The Edo State
            Government is fully committed to the objectives of the
            Development Policy Operation (DPO). This will be the first
            extension of the project.

Nigeria - First Edo State Growth
            and Employment Support Credit Project : restructuring (Vol.
            2) : Data sheet

repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - First Edo State Growth and
            Employment Support Credit Project : summary of discussion

abstracts.cdata!:
The Executive Directors approved a
            single-tranche credit to the Federal Republic of Nigeria for
            the First Edo State Growth and Employment Support Program in
            the amount of SDR 48.4 million (US$ 75 million equivalent)
            on the payment terms and conditions set out in the
            President's Memorandum. The Directors underscored the
            program's critical role in engendering reforms critical
            to growth, employment, and improved service delivery, not
            only in Edo State, but in other Nigerian states as well,
            through the expected positive demonstration effects. They
            noted the risk mitigation measures and underscored the
            importance of complementary technical assistance to deal
            with weak implementation capacity. They emphasized that such
            support, together with the Bank's supervision missions,
            will be critical to ensure the program achieves its
            development objectives.

repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - First Edo State Growth and
            Employment Support Credit Program

abstracts.cdata!:
The First Edo State Growth and
            Employment Support Credit Program main policy areas
            supported are: (a) improving the management of public
            resources in implementing an infrastructure-oriented
            development strategy by ensuring fiscal sustainability and
            improving budgeting institutions and practices; (b)
            improving the institutional and policy environment for
            growth and employment creation by improving investment
            climate and the quality of education. A cross-cutting theme
            running through these policy areas is that of improving
            social accountability. This program document proposes the
            first growth and employment support credit to the State of
            Edo for SDR 48.4 (US$75 million). It will be the first
            operation in a series of three annual programmatic
            development policy operations, with a planned total of
            US$225 million, that are aimed at supporting the
            Government's policy and institutional reform program in
            the implementation of the state's medium-term
            development strategy that is itself focused on growth and
            employment creation. In spite of progress made in service
            delivery, challenges still remain, including the need to
            ensure sustainability of the gains made. The infrastructure
            development needs still abound with huge financing gaps to
            be filled. For instance, there are still many schools at
            various levels of education requiring rehabilitation.
            Similarly, although work has begun on the master plan of the
            Benin City storm water drainage system, the financing
            requirements of its full implementation are immense.
            Finally, Government systems remain largely weak which
            threatens the long-term sustainability of progress. Going
            forward, the Government's overall strategy is to
            mobilize more resources, including from external sources,
            and to strengthen systems and institutions for sustained progress.

docna.cdata!:
Nigeria - First Edo State Growth and
            Employment Support Credit Program

display_title.display_title:
Nigeria - First Edo State Growth
            and Employment Support Credit Program
